author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- Name does not meet all of the following: starts with an upper-case letter, ASCII alphanumerics only, not all letters are upper-case.
- The following dependencies do not have a `[compat]` entry that is upper-bounded and only includes a finite number of breaking releases: DataFrames, Distributions, Documenter

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simply retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. Then, send a message to the `#pkg-registration` channel in the [Julia Slack](https://julialang.org/slack/) to ask for help. Include a link to this pull request.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Hi, and congrats on the registration!
Can I suggest a more specific name? Without functional docs it's hard to understand what your package does, but the general registry namespace is rather precious and `pvalue` would be a very coveted spot

Hi!

I'll think about it. Indeed it is package providing functions to compute
p-values. Do you have any suggestions? I have just changed the name to
PValue to comply with the guidelines.

Bye,
 Stefano

Il giorno mer 24 apr 2024 alle ore 14:58 Guillaume Dalle <
***@***.***> ha scritto:

> Hi, and congrats on the registration!
> Can I suggest a more specific name? Without functional docs it's hard to
> understand what your package does, but the general registry namespace is
> rather precious and pvalue would be a very coveted spot
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/105535#issuecomment-2074889740>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAGVYHF77ORIHG5YIRVY4WLY66T7VAVCNFSM6AAAAABGWZUPACVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMZDANZUHA4DSNZUGA>
> .

-- 
———————————————————————————

Il miglior modo per avere una buona idea è avere tante idee.


Linus Pauling



Stefano Covino

INAF / Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera

Via Emilio Bianchi 46, 23807

Merate (LC) - Italy

Tel.: +39 02 72320475 (office)

FAX: +39 02 72320401

Cell: +39 331 6748534

E-mail: ***@***.***

URL: http://www.merate.mi.astro.it/∼covino
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

After a quick look, I found that

- [StatsBase.jl](https://juliastats.org/StatsBase.jl/0.19.1/statmodels.html) already implements AIC, BIC, etc.
- [HypothesisTests.jl](https://juliastats.org/HypothesisTests.jl/stable/methods/#p-value) has one type of $p$-value
- the other functions like RMS and SSR are simple enough that they don't need to be in a package

If you're up for it, my suggestion would be to try and contribute your alternative $p$-values to HypothesisTests.jl in order to make one library better instead of creating a new one. What do you think?

Dear Guillamme,

Indeed, it is good advice. I'll contact the HypothesisTests maintainers.

Thanks a lot for you time,
  Stefano



Il giorno mer 24 apr 2024 alle ore 15:25 Guillaume Dalle <
***@***.***> ha scritto:

>

> I have just changed the name to `PValue` to comply with the guidelines.

I'll close this, then. I also agree it would be better that to contribute this functionality to an existing package.

body:
- Registering package: pValue
- Repository: https://github.com/stefanocovino/pValue.jl
- Created by: @stefanocovino
- Version: v0.8.2
- Commit: 9f5dd4dbccf38f2b28080290fb935598d9fac31a
- Git reference: HEAD
- Description: A simple package including several Julia functions to compute p-values in a "frequentist" or "Bayesian" scenario.
title: New package: pValue v0.8.2
